message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Diversity begets stability: Sublinear growth and competitive coexistence across ecosystems
Paper Abstract: The worldwide loss of species diversity brings urgency to understanding how diverse ecosystems maintain stability. Whereas early ecological ideas and classic observations suggested that stability increases with diversity, ecological theory makes the opposite prediction, leading to the long-standing “diversity-stability debate.” Here, we show that this puzzle can be resolved if growth scales as a sublinear power law with biomass (exponent <1), exhibiting a form of population self-regulation analogous to models of individual ontogeny. We show that competitive interactions among populations with sublinear growth do not lead to exclusion, as occurs with logistic growth, but instead promote stability at higher diversity. Our model realigns theory with classic observations and predicts large-scale macroecological patterns. However, it makes an unsettling prediction: Biodiversity loss may accelerate the destabilization of ecosystems.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've completed a web search for "species diversity." Here's what I found:

## Definition and Basics

Species diversity is the number of different species that are represented in a given community. More specifically, species diversity is the relationship between species evenness and species richness, where species richness is the number of species present in a given area.

## Measuring Species Diversity

Common diversity indices include species richness, the Shannon index, the Simpson index, and the complement of the Simpson index (also known as the Gini-Simpson index). Alpha diversity refers to diversity within a particular area, community or ecosystem, beta diversity is species diversity between ecosystems, and gamma diversity is a measurement of the overall diversity for different ecosystems within a region.

## Global Species Estimates

According to estimates, there are approximately 8.7 million terrestrial species and 2.2 million oceanic species. However, human activities have led to an ongoing biodiversity loss and an accompanying loss of genetic diversity.

## Related Concepts

Functional diversity is often referred to as the "value and the range of those species and organismal traits that influence ecosystem functioning", which is related to but distinct from species diversity itself.

## Definition and Basics

Species diversity is the number of different species that are represented in a given community. More specifically, species diversity is the relationship between species evenness and species richness, where species richness is the number of species present in a given area.

## Measuring Species Diversity

Common diversity indices include species richness, the Shannon index, the Simpson index, and the complement of the Simpson index (also known as the Gini-Simpson index). Alpha diversity refers to diversity within a particular area, community or ecosystem, beta diversity is species diversity between ecosystems, and gamma diversity is a measurement of the overall diversity for different ecosystems within a region.

## Global Species Estimates

According to estimates, there are approximately 8.7 million terrestrial species and 2.2 million oceanic species. However, human activities have led to an ongoing biodiversity loss and an accompanying loss of genetic diversity.

## Related Concepts

Functional diversity is often referred to as the "value and the range of those species and organismal traits that influence ecosystem functioning", which is related to but distinct from species diversity itself.

Links: [{"title":"Ecological stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_stability"},{"title":"Alternative stable state - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alternative_stable_state"},{"title":"Ecological effects of biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_effects_of_biodiversity"},{"title":"Resistance (ecology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resistance_(ecology)"},{"title":"Evelyn Chrystalla Pielou - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evelyn_Chrystalla_Pielou"},{"title":"Hainan black crested gibbon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hainan_black_crested_gibbon"}]

I've completed the web search for "ecosystem stability". Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Concept

In ecology, an ecosystem is said to possess ecological stability (or equilibrium) if it is capable of returning to its equilibrium state after a perturbation (a capacity known as resilience) or does not experience unexpected large changes in its characteristics across time.

## Key Components of Stability

Researchers have proposed replacing the general term "ecological stability" with more specific terms, such as constancy, resilience and persistence.(no content)The three fundamental properties of ecological stability are: "staying essentially unchanged," "returning to the reference state after a temporary disturbance" and "persistence through time of an ecological system."

## Diversity and Stability

More biologically diverse communities appear to be more productive (in terms of biomass production) than are less diverse communities, and they appear to be more stable in the face of perturbations.(no content)Diversity can enhance the stability of ecosystem functions at various ecological scales, and genetic diversity can enhance resistance to environmental perturbations.

## Alternative Stable States

Ecosystems may transition from one stable state to another in what is known as a state shift when perturbed, and due to ecological feedbacks, ecosystems display resistance to state shifts and therefore tend to remain in one state unless perturbations are large enough.

Web search results for query: "power law"

Links: [{"title":"Power law - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_law"},{"title":"Stevens's power law - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stevens's_power_law"},{"title":"Fourth power law - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fourth_power_law"},{"title":"Power law scheme - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_law_scheme"},{"title":"Power-law fluid - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power-law_fluid"},{"title":"Power-law index profile - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power-law_index_profile"},{"title":"Category:Power laws - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Power_laws"},{"title":"Power law of practice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_law_of_practice"},{"title":"The 48 Laws of Power - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_48_Laws_of_Power"},{"title":"Power law of cache misses - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_law_of_cache_misses"}]

Here are the search results for "power law":

## General Definition

In statistics, a power law is a functional relationship between two quantities, where a relative change in one quantity results in a relative change in the other quantity proportional to the change raised to a constant exponent.

## Examples and Applications

Power laws appear in the sizes of craters on the moon, solar flares, cloud sizes, foraging patterns of species, neuronal populations, word frequencies in languages, and many other natural phenomena.

Specific applications include:
- Income distribution, which follows a power law known as the Pareto distribution
- Stevens' power law describes the relationship between increased physical stimulus intensity and perceived sensation
- The power law of practice states that reaction time decreases linearly with the logarithm of practice trials
- The fourth power law states that stress on roads from vehicles increases in proportion to the fourth power of axle load

## Research and Importance

Research on power-law relations is an active topic across physics, computer science, linguistics, geophysics, neuroscience, and other scientific fields. However, empirical distributions can only fit a power law for a limited range of values, because a pure power law would allow for arbitrarily large or small values.

Web search results for query: "ontogeny growth"

Links: [{"title":"Ontogeny - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ontogeny"},{"title":"Recapitulation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recapitulation_theory"},{"title":"Ontogeny and Phylogeny - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ontogeny_and_phylogeny"},{"title":"Life history theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Life_history_theory"},{"title":"Colony (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colony_(biology)"},{"title":"Heterochrony - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heterochrony"},{"title":"Tinbergen's four questions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tinbergen's_four_questions"},{"title":"Sociogeny - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sociogeny"},{"title":"Ontogeny (psychoanalysis) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ontogeny_(psychoanalysis)"},{"title":"Ontogenetic depth - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ontogenetic_depth"}]

Here are the search results for "ontogeny growth":

## Definition and Overview

Ontogeny (also ontogenesis) is the origination and development of an organism (both physical and psychological, e.g., moral development), usually from the time of fertilization of the egg to adult.(no content)Ontogeny is the growth (size change) and development (structure change) of an individual organism.(no content)Ontogeny is the developmental history of an organism within its own lifetime, as distinct from phylogeny, which refers to the evolutionary history of a species.

## Key Aspects of Ontogeny

Aspects of ontogeny are morphogenesis, the development of form and shape of an organism; tissue growth; and cellular differentiation.(no content)Ontogeny is an important field of study in many disciplines, including developmental biology, cell biology, genetics, developmental psychology, developmental cognitive neuroscience, and developmental psychobiology.

## Historical Background

The term ontogeny was coined by Ernst Haeckel, a German zoologist and evolutionist in the 1860s.(no content)Haeckel suggested a biogenetic law that ontogeny recapitulates phylogeny, based on the idea that the successive and progressive origin of new species was based on the same laws as the successive and progressive origin of new embryonic structures.

## Life History Context

Each species has its own pattern and timing for life stages, often known as its ontogeny.

Links: [{"title":"Logistic function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_function"},{"title":"Logistic growth model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Logistic_growth_model&redirect=no"},{"title":"Generalised logistic function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generalised_logistic_function"},{"title":"Ricker model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ricker_model"},{"title":"Gompertz function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gompertz_function"},{"title":"Competitive Lotka–Volterra equations","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competitive_Lotka–Volterra_equations"},{"title":"Population dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_dynamics"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Modelling Wikipedia's growth - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Modelling_Wikipedia's_growth"},{"title":"Population growth - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_growth"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about the logistic growth model:

## Overview

The logistic function was introduced in a series of three papers by Pierre François Verhulst between 1838 and 1847, who devised it as a model of population growth by adjusting the exponential growth model.

## How It Works

The initial stage of growth is approximately exponential (geometric); then, as saturation begins, the growth slows to linear (arithmetic), and at maturity, growth approaches the limit with an exponentially decaying gap, like the initial stage in reverse.

## Mathematical Formulation

Malthus' population principle of growth was later transformed into a mathematical model known as the logistic equation: dN/dt = rN(1 − N/K), where N is the population size, r is the intrinsic rate of natural increase, and K is the carrying capacity of the population.(no content)The formula can be read as follows: the rate of change in the population (dN/dt) is equal to growth (rN) that is limited by carrying capacity (1 − N/K).

## Applications

The logistic growth model has diverse applications:

- A typical application of the logistic equation is a common model of population growth, originally due to Pierre-François Verhulst in 1838, where the rate of reproduction is proportional to both the existing population and the amount of available resources, all else being equal.

- In medicine, the logistic differential equation can be used to model the growth of tumors.

- Epidemic curves first linearizing and then reaching a maximal limit. A logistic function is usually used in a descriptive or phenomenological manner because it fits well not only to the early exponential rise, but to the eventual levelling off of the pandemic.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about macroecology:

## Definition and Approach

Macroecology is a subfield in ecology that uses a methodological approach to investigate empirical patterns and mechanistic processes by which the particulate components of complex ecological systems generate emergent structures and dynamics. Unlike traditional ecology, which focuses on local and small-scale interactions, macroecology seeks to identify general emergent patterns within and across spatial and temporal scales.

## Core Principles

One of the main tenets of macroecology is that, despite the apparent complexity and randomness of ecological systems, they exhibit a significant degree of order. This order is particularly evident in statistical patterns related to organism interactions, their relationships with the environment, and the emergent structures and dynamics of ecological systems.(no content)Macroecology adopts a "top-down" approach, focusing on understanding the properties of entire systems (populations, communities, assemblages etc.) rather than individual components. It is akin to seeing the entire forest instead of individual trees.

## History

The term "macroecology" was first introduced by Venezuelan researchers Guillermo Sarmiento and Maximina Monasterio in 1971 and was later adopted by James Brown and Brian Maurer in their 1989 paper in Science.

## Key Areas of Study

Some critical areas of interest within macroecology include the study of species richness, latitudinal gradients in species diversity, the species-area curve, range size, body size, and species abundance. Specifically, the relationship between abundance and range size—exploring why some species are widespread and abundant while others are restricted and less common—has been a focal area of macroecological research.

Links: [{"title":"Population dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_dynamics"},{"title":"Pest insect population dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pest_insect_population_dynamics"},{"title":"Population dynamics of fisheries - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_dynamics_of_fisheries"},{"title":"Population model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_model"},{"title":"Population ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_ecology"},{"title":"Matrix population models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrix_population_models"},{"title":"Source–sink dynamics","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Source–sink_dynamics"},{"title":"Malthusian growth model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malthusian_growth_model"},{"title":"Metapopulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metapopulation"},{"title":"León Mario Bedoya - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Le%C3%B3n_Mario_Bedoya"}]

I've completed the web search for "population dynamics." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

Population dynamics is the type of mathematics used to model and study the size and age composition of populations as dynamical systems.(no content)It is a branch of mathematical biology that uses mathematical techniques such as differential equations to model behavior.

## Scope and Applications

Population dynamics describes the ways in which a given population grows and shrinks over time, as controlled by birth, death, and migration, and serves as the basis for understanding changing fishery patterns and issues such as habitat destruction, predation and optimal harvesting rates.

## Key Variables

Simplified population models usually start with four key variables (four demographic processes) including death, birth, immigration, and emigration.

## Historical Development

The beginning of population dynamics is widely regarded as the work of Malthus, formulated as the Malthusian growth model, which proposes that assuming constant environmental conditions, a population will grow or decline exponentially.(no content)One of the most basic and milestone models of population growth was the logistic model of population growth formulated by Pierre François Verhulst in 1838.

## Modern Applications

Population models are used to determine maximum harvest for agriculturists, to understand the dynamics of biological invasions, for environmental conservation, and to understand the spread of parasites, viruses, and disease.

Population dynamics is the type of mathematics used to model and study the size and age composition of populations as dynamical systems.(no content)It is a branch of mathematical biology that uses mathematical techniques such as differential equations to model behavior.

## Scope and Applications

Population dynamics describes the ways in which a given population grows and shrinks over time, as controlled by birth, death, and migration, and serves as the basis for understanding changing fishery patterns and issues such as habitat destruction, predation and optimal harvesting rates.

## Key Variables

Simplified population models usually start with four key variables (four demographic processes) including death, birth, immigration, and emigration.

## Historical Development

The beginning of population dynamics is widely regarded as the work of Malthus, formulated as the Malthusian growth model, which proposes that assuming constant environmental conditions, a population will grow or decline exponentially.(no content)One of the most basic and milestone models of population growth was the logistic model of population growth formulated by Pierre François Verhulst in 1838.

## Modern Applications

Population models are used to determine maximum harvest for agriculturists, to understand the dynamics of biological invasions, for environmental conservation, and to understand the spread of parasites, viruses, and disease.

Web search results for query: "competition ecology"

Links: [{"title":"Competition (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition_(biology)"},{"title":"Interspecific competition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interspecific_competition"},{"title":"Ecological model of competition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_model_of_competition"},{"title":"Contest competition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contest_competition"},{"title":"Scramble competition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scramble_competition"},{"title":"Lottery competition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lottery_competition"},{"title":"Competitive exclusion principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competitive_exclusion_principle"},{"title":"R* rule (ecology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/R*_rule_(ecology)"},{"title":"G. David Tilman - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G._David_Tilman"},{"title":"Intraspecific competition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intraspecific_competition"}]

The search results provide comprehensive information about competition in ecology. Here are the key findings:

## Definition

Competition is an interaction between organisms or species in which both require one or more resources that are in limited supply (such as food, water, or territory).

## Types of Competition

**Intraspecific vs. Interspecific:**
- Intraspecific competition is an interaction in population ecology, whereby members of the same species compete for limited resources.
- Interspecific competition is a form of competition in which individuals of different species compete for the same resources in an ecosystem.

**Contest vs. Scramble:**
- Contest competition refers to a situation where available resources, such as food and mates, are utilized only by one or a few individuals, thus preventing development or reproduction of other individuals.
- Scramble competition refers to a situation in which a resource is accessible to all competitors (that is, it is not monopolizable by an individual or group).

**Mechanisms:**
There are three major mechanisms of competition: interference, exploitation, and apparent competition (in order from most direct to least direct).

## Effects and Principles

Competition lowers the fitness of both organisms involved since the presence of one of the organisms always reduces the amount of the resource available to the other.(no content)The competitive exclusion principle is a proposition that two species which compete for the same limited resource cannot coexist at constant population sizes. However, species can coexist through mechanisms like niche differentiation, a process by which competitive exclusion leads to differences in resource use. In some cases, niche differentiation results in spatial displacement, where species avoid direct competition by occupying different areas.

Web search results for query: "biodiversity loss extinction"

Links: [{"title":"Biodiversity loss - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity_loss"},{"title":"Extinction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extinction"},{"title":"Habitat destruction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Habitat_destruction"},{"title":"Holocene extinction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holocene_extinction"},{"title":"Extinction risk from climate change - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extinction_risk_from_climate_change"},{"title":"Biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity"},{"title":"Extinction event - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extinction_event"},{"title":"Ecological effects of biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_effects_of_biodiversity"},{"title":"Ecological extinction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_extinction"},{"title":"Ecosystem collapse - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecosystem_collapse"}]

I've completed the web search for "biodiversity loss extinction." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Current Biodiversity Crisis

The fast-growing extinction trends of various animal groups like mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, and fish have led scientists to declare a current biodiversity crisis in both land and ocean ecosystems.(no content)The current rate of global biodiversity loss is estimated to be 100 to 1000 times higher than the naturally occurring background extinction rate, faster than at any other time in human history, and is expected to grow in the upcoming years.

## Scale of the Problem

In 2021, about 28 percent of the 134,400 species assessed using the IUCN Red List criteria are now listed as threatened with extinction—a total of 37,400 species compared to 16,119 threatened species in 2006.(no content)A 2022 study that surveyed more than 3,000 experts found that "global biodiversity loss and its impacts may be greater than previously thought", and estimated that roughly 30% of species "have been globally threatened or driven extinct since the year 1500."

## Major Causes

Habitat destruction is in fact the leading cause of biodiversity loss and species extinction worldwide.(no content)Causes include habitat destruction, such as intensive agriculture, the use of pesticides (particularly insecticides), introduced species, and – to a lesser degree and only for some regions – the effects of climate change.

## Human Responsibility

The ongoing Holocene extinction is caused primarily by human impact on the environment, and the greatest biodiversity loss so far had been due to habitat degradation and fragmentation, which eventually destroys entire ecosystems if left unchecked.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as 'contribution' or 'survey'. Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

purpose: Extract transferable techniques and methodologies from research papers

message_text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** **Contribution**

This paper proposes a novel theoretical framework (sublinear power law growth model) that resolves the long-standing diversity-stability debate in ecology.

**Extracted Triples (9 entities):**

| Entity | Type | Relation | Why It Matters |
|--------|------|----------|----------------|
| [Species diversity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Species_diversity) | concept | uses | Core topic examining how species diversity affects ecosystem stability |
| [Ecological stability](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_stability) | concept | uses | Main property of ecosystems investigated in relation to diversity |
| [Logistic function](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_function) | method | uses | Baseline model used for comparison against the proposed sublinear growth model |
| [Power law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_law) | concept | **proposes** | Novel sublinear power law growth model for how population growth scales with biomass |
| [Ontogeny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ontogeny) | concept | uses | Analogy used to motivate the sublinear growth model for population self-regulation |
| [Population dynamics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_dynamics) | task | uses | Mathematical framework for modeling competitive interactions between populations |
| [Competition (biology)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition_(biology)) | concept | uses | Examines how competitive interactions change with different growth models |
| [Macroecology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Macroecology) | concept | **proposes** | Large-scale macroecological patterns explained by the sublinear growth model |
| [Biodiversity loss](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity_loss) | task | uses | Global challenge directly addressed by predictions of ecosystem destabilization |

**Validation Status:** ✅ All checks passed successfully

Sources:
